advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> PROMOTIONAL PICT. #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Larry Greenfield and his <a href="http://www.tcp.com/%7Elgreenf/apfpage.htm" target="_blank">APF Imagination Machine page</a> for this picture</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <a href="http://www.cobit.kit.net" target="_blank">COB-Clube Old Bits</a> for this picture.</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Karl-Heinz - www.sharpmz.org</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> DISK DRIVE #1 JAN. 1982</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b><a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a></b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT#2 (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Here comes Sirius 1 : the micro-computer which has an elephant memory"<br> ...<br> "A new era for computing"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert dated december 1983, says: "A true computing system: 3590F".<br> 3590F was approx. 547 euros, which was cheaper than a TO-7 alone one year earlier. <br><br> This box contained: a TO-7 computer, Basic cartridge with doc, Joystick/Music expansion, 2 joysticks, TRAP game and PICTOR software. This was a special offer for christmas 83. <br><br> On the whole box is written: "A smart present for the whole family". </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> IN SCHOOLS #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1981)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Sharp 1211 advert from ILLEL, a french computer seller</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST U.S. ADVERT (1977)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> VICTOR AD #4 (1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> AN ADVERTISING</strong></font><br><blockquote>I couldn't resist putting this photo here. The girl looks very happy, the ad said "The new System III can be provided with walnut floor cabinet".</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBURRY BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk </b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> BROCHURE #3</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JANUARY 1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"At 68 years old, taunt Rose discovered that she was an exceptionally gifted child"</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (APRIL 1987)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"You're never so well served than by yourself..." <br><br> "...create your own micro-server on Thomson."</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Juraj Mucko for this picture </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> INSERT - VERSO</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CHARLIE CHAPLIN #3 </strong></font><br><blockquote>1983 - Before the IBM PC became THE universal standard, IBM was looking for good programs using all the features IBM Basic could offer.<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Let your imagination take wing.<br> Think charts, Graphs, Shapes, Images.<br> Use originality, creativity and color in programs that entertain, educate, organize, analyse. And programs that get down to business...<br> ...In fact, if you are interested in licensing your software, we could be interested in publishing it...</font> </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"It's him" <br><br> This is not an Apple official advert, but from french distributor called Micro Informatique Diffusion (MID)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PRIMO ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBRAIN BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Newbrain brochure only offered two models:<br><br> Model AD: with display<br> Model A: without Display <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b> </p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> UK ADVERT, OCT 1983 </strong></font><br><blockquote>Probably the last advert made by T.I. in the UK</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> JAPANESE AD #1</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

computer.builtInGames: 7 games (Flipper pinball 1, Flipper pinball 2, Racket pinball 1, Racket pinball 2, Basketball 1, Basketball 2, Breakout)
computer.description:
This funky pong is the japanese version of the Atari Video Pinball C-380 (and the Sears Pinball Breakaway).
It plays seven games: Flipper pinball 1, Flipper pinball 2, Racket pinball 1, Racket pinball 2, Basketball 1, Basketball 2 and Breakout. All these games are in fact improved pong games.
All the games are controlled by the big white dial placed on the right part of the system, except the two flipper pinball games which must be played with the two side buttons, just like with a real pinball!
Apparently there were a TV Block MB model which had slightly different games (?). Instead of 2 basketball games and 1 breakout game, there were only one basketball game and 2 breakout games.
computer.keyboard: 2 side buttons (to play flipper pinball games) and one big knob to play other games (paddle games)
computer.language: 7 games (Flipper pinball 1, Flipper pinball 2, Racket pinball 1, Racket pinball 2, Basketball 1, Basketball 2, Breakout)
computer.name: TV Block
computer.ports: RF TV video output, power in
computer.power: 6 x UM2 sized battery cells or external power supply
